title: Odd benefit of being in car behind Queen
text:

When members of the Royal Family travel to official events their convoy of cars is normally ranked in order of seniority.

Prince Charles, his sons William and Harry and their wives Camilla, the Duchess of Cambridge and Meghan Markle often sit in the front cars or carriages while those further down the line of success are behind.

But according to Prince Edward, the Queen's youngest son, there is a huge benefit to this - and he much prefers it.

Speaking during a TV interview, he said: "Without a shadow of a doubt, one of the best entertainments is being in the car behind the Queen’s car, because that’s where you see all the reactions – especially in places where they’re not expecting to see the Queen , that’s even better."

(Image: WireImage)

His wife Sophie adds: "And we open the window just a little bit, so we can hear what people are saying."

Edward also opened up about his first ever royal engagement, saying he was given "absolutely no instruction whatsoever" of what he actually needed to do.

His parents the Queen and Prince Philip walked off ahead, leaving him and his brother Prince Andrew behind.

He said: "I remember vividly the awful realisation that we were going to have to walk through this corridor of people because the cars – I couldn’t even see the cars, they were around the corner – and our parents just walked off and started talking to people.

(Image: Popperfoto via Getty Images)

"And I thought: 'Well, I can either walk down the middle like a complete lemon or…'

"I think my brother was there as well, so we just said: 'You go that side, I’ll go this side', but there was absolutely no instruction whatsoever.

"I think the only piece of advice I was given was: 'Don’t treat it like a receiving line'.

"So don’t start shaking hands, because once you have shaken one person’s hand you are completely stuck – you have to shake everybody’s hand."

(Image: Getty Images)

While he avoids shaking hands on walkabouts, the Earl does of course shake hands at official events and while meeting important figures.

Despite not being very senior when it comes to the family structure, the Queen is said to be very close to Sophie and enjoys her company.

A royal source told the Sun that the Monarch will often ask Sophie Wessex to join her in the car on their journey to church if they are both in Sandringham or Balmoral.

The Countess of Wessex is married to Prince Edward, the Queen's youngest son, and the couple have two children Lady Louise Windsor and James Viscount Severn.

The insider said: "The Queen likes to be completely calm before church and she finds Sophie’s presence soothing."

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

When Sophie married Edward she decided against becoming a working royal, insisting on continuing her work in public relations.

The insider added: "She is trusted and relied on by the Queen in a way I couldn't say applied to the Duchess of Cambridge or the Duchess of Cornwall.

"She is like another daughter to Her Majesty, they are that close."

(Image: REX/Shutterstock)

Edward is the only one of the Queen's children who is still married to their first partner, which the source says the Queen "knows that is in no small way down to Sophie’s dedication - she is aware, as his Edward’s mother, what a tricky creature he can be".

And the Queen isn't the only member of the Royal Family who looks to Sophie for help, and she has reportedly been an "unofficial mentor and ally" to Meghan Markle .

Royal Biographer Katie Nicholl revealed in Grazia that the Queen "earmarked" Sophie as a royal mentor for Meghan.

The two -in-laws spent time together at Royal Ascot last year and are believed to get along well.
description: The Queen's son Prince Edward and his wife Sophie Wessex carry out official engagements with the Queen, but they prefer sitting in the car behind her whenever they can
